pros: You learn a lot about being a secretary, you receive knowledge on the inner workings of a campus, friendly atmosphere.
cons: Sometimes don't work with students schedule.

review_title: Good people, Low pay, No housing
pros: Excellent senior leadership and a highly collaborative community of faculty and staff. Steadily evolving from an insular rural outpost to a modern, regional, comprehensive, public university. A combination of cutting-edge practices and the Dark Ages simultaneously. The natural setting is stunning.
cons: Some really horrible middle management who have been here way too long. Pay is abysmal and personnel management can be downright draconian. What should be a purple state has been gerrymandered into a burgeoning right-wing nuthouse. The UNC System may not survive another 10 years of a Redneck Cultural Revolution.

pros: - Consistent income - Attentive supervisors - Acceptable compensation
cons: - 24/7 availability needed - Very little time off - Unorganized

job_title: Campus Recreation Supervisor in Cullowhee, NC

job_title: Associate Professor of Practice in Charlotte, NC

cons: middle of no where, not to much to do

pros: Fun work culture and caring supervisors
cons: Low pay and few hours

job_title: Director, Media Relations in Cullowhee, NC
pros: Insurance is best part of the job

job_title: Health Communications Specialist in Cullowhee, NC
pros: Staff is very tight knit and welcoming
cons: Days were unpredictable in terms of business. One day might be very uneventful and the next you might get swamped with phone calls.

review_title: Best place I have worked in Higher Ed
pros: After working in some toxic environments through my career, becoming a part of the advising center team reignited why I went into higher education in the first place. Leadership genuinely cares about each staff member, and all staff are passionate about their students and institution. I have watched WCU time and time again step up to do the right thing to make sure all students feel safe, welcome, and valued over the past three years, during a time when our country was ripped by racism, sexism, political turmoil, and a pandemic. My department was no exception in ensuring that best practices in student services and equity were at the forefront of all of our programming and day to days operations. Anyone who says any different must have been either living under a rock or viewing the world through a small minded, emotionally immature, and ego centric perspective.
cons: Zero. I literally love working for WCU. If you have an opportunity to apply for a position here, you should. We are in the mountains so city life is not part of our lifestyle. It might be a culture shock to some but it’s home to many.

pros:
20hr/wk split between TA work with professors and working on graduate work (thesis or directed project). TA work is usually straightforward things like grading homework or sitting in and helping with lab/class.
"Looks good on your resume" according to professors.
cons:
Pay is not competitive enough to keep up with the increasing rent cost around Cullowhee and the surrounding area. 
The contract with the school is very strict about secondary employment (they usually don't allow it, though several grad students have secondary employment anyway on the weekends). I've been consistently eating into my checking and savings account to keep up with my rent and bills.

pros: There are a variety of jobs available for multiple majors on campus.
cons: You really have to learn how to balance work and school. While they are forgiving and know school comes first, they expect your best work when possible.

review_title: Good University - Pay Needs to Improve
pros: Beautiful Mountain Location, lots of resources, faculty support for things like travel to conferences and research
cons: Lowest pay in the UNC System. Lowest pay compared to peer institutions. High cost of living area. Hard to find a decent, affordable place to live.

pros: Great place to work for people.
cons: It is good no cons.

pros:

cons: * 77% of state salary because "rural"

pros: Close knit community, collegial environment, beautiful campus, great location for outdoor activities and small-town life.
cons: Salaries aren't market rate. Limited career growth. Strict adherence to "traditional" residential college mindset. Promises of flexiblity, raises, advocacy, support, etc, are never fulfilled. Executive Leadership refuses to adapt to a changing world.

review_title: Higher Education with a Family/Community Feel
pros: Rural, mountainous region, best outdoor activities, loves their people, supports their employees, and overall wants to see not only students success but faculty and staff as well.
cons: we are a rural Appalachian community and our region as well as our university could benefit greatly from greater DEI.

pros: Small community and decent benefits.
cons: Surrounding towns can be boring and/or closed-minded.

pros: Very lax and helpful. They also back you up and support your decisions. The duties are also relatively light so it's an easy way to pay for your degree.
cons: There is nothing really to complain about. The only real drawback is that they do kind of throw you into the deep end and give you no real training in how to teach lab (or what I should be looking for in the process) but since I have taken labs before I know kinda how to run it. The only bad thing is at the end of the semester the students will write bad reviews if they didn't get a good grade but all those reviews do is hurt my ego so over all a good job to pay your way through your masters.

review_title: Great place to work at for a work-study position.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Cullowhee, NC
pros: This position was an assistantship awarded to graduate students in master's degree programs. The position was mostly acting as a teaching assistant to various professors, helping with whatever tasks that were generally more time-consuming and monotonous for the professors. The workload was noticeable, but not large enough to actively interfere with classes or thesis research. The professors that I worked for were generally very understanding of my master's degree workload and were always willing to work with me to ensure that I didn't fall behind on classes or my thesis while still fulfilling my responsibilities to them. The stipend that the position paid out was large enough to afford rent on a apartment nearby campus and cover monthly expenses.
cons: The pay schedule was inconvenient. The assistantship award package was paid out in four installments at the end of every month, with the exception of the first month of the semester. This generally meant that people with the assistantship had to figure out how to pay rent and buy food for roughly 1.5 months without pay until the stipends started getting paid.

review_title: Working here was not what I thought it would be!!!
job_title: Director of IT in Cullowhee, NC
pros: If you like to work out in the country, than this is a good place too do that.  You can experience all 4 of the seasons and beautiful mountain views.
cons: Working at a University I would have thought that the focus would have been towards he student and do what you could to aid them with gaining the best education they could.  Shockingly I was wrong in what I had learned while working here.  Most of the money is spent to better department heads, to better them self and not the students.  I had student computer labs with computers that better then 8 years old.  When asked for money to take care of this and to better the education of the students, I was told that there weren't any funds to take care of this.

review_title: Buddy buddy culture will prevent full potential.
pros: They employee a decent amount of students. Most departments will work with you as a student to schedule you around your classes.
cons: The buddy culture here means that if you dont go to the right church, or right social club, you have no chance of getting a full time position. Drama is high for a low pay job. I would only recommend if you never want to leave the area. IT is the worst for the buddy culture though. Also if you report anything to HR such as harassment or unfair practices, they will do nothing except send it back to your boss, dealt with that first hand.

job_title: Information Technology Specialist in Cullowhee, NC
pros: Western Carolina University is an exceptional organization. It is diverse in culture and fair in its policies; it provides benefits that far surpass any other organization I have worked for in the last 10 years and maintains a competitive pay structure. Western Carolina University also provides much more training and development than my previous organization. The culture and work-life balance is well above par for the region.
cons: Western Carolina suffers from underfunding, but is doing remarkably well as part of an outstanding state university system that has been hit with the many side-effects of a polarized political environment that has (negatively) impacted funding for over 8 years.

pros: Wonderful colleagues and students who are truly engaged in their studies.
cons: The work of contingent faculty is undervalued at this university. Fixed-term faculty members are paid less at this UNC system member institution than those at others of similar rank and with similar student profiles. WCU employs accounting "tricks" to take advantage of our credit hour generation while simultaneously keeping our pay substandard. There is absolutely no possibility for advancement and this university rarely hires from within. This is a dead end job paying near poverty wages.

review_title: A Student Job with balance of studies!
job_title: IT Student Worker in Cullowhee, NC
pros: Amazing experience with great staff to work with!  Fellow student workers are helpful and very team based, and full time members are not only there to work with you but also help you in your career goals as well.
cons: None that I can see currently, it is a student job, so pay will not be high.  Also hours are at a premium some days due to scheduling.  However this is not the fault of staff, just the situation of what it is.

pros: The outside environment ie the mountains is great place to be. There are some good faculty and staff members with the emphasis being on some.
cons: If you are a person of color it is not a welcoming environment. There is  no support and you will feel alone and secluded just like the mountains. Too much of the buddy system around there. If you are in the clique, then you can make it. If you are not, then you need to get out of there as soon as possible.  Less than 2% of your faculty and staff are minorities... that is a problem.

review_title: Be careful if you’re not local
pros: Beautiful setting for a university, many opportunities for  first generation students, breaks between semesters are fairly quiet opportunities to get research done.
cons: Very little guidance or support from other faculty, department head, or dean. Expectation to always take on more work despite an already high workload. Very difficult to fit in if you’re from out-if-town— a surprisingly high number of faculty attended WCU as students. I think it’s difficult to draw in new faculty because of the remote rural location, very low salary, and high workload.

pros: The school has a nice small sized and laid back feel to it. A good university for those to work or study at seeking a more slow paced atmosphere.
cons: The universitiy is way out in the middle of no-where, literally, in an area with little to no economic growth. The fastest long-distance way to get there is to fly to asheville and drive 1 hour west. Since the University is small there are a small number of jobs and good luck getting decent non-WCU jobs around that area.

pros: Wonderful co-workers. High degree of on-the-job training. Unique setting in the beautiful Appalachian Mountains at Western Carolina University. Open to the public and closely coordinated with other local museums.
cons: Basement office has very little light. Parking is across the street for students. Some circulation problems in the HVAC system.

pros: Supportive environment with wonderful staff, faculty, students and administration.  Breathtaking scenic campus and area.
cons: Upward mobility limited.  Depending on the department, outside hires can be preferred.  In some cases cliques exist, but nothing too out of ordinary.  Self-sacrificial workoholoc atmosphere abounds.  No extra money to be had for working weekends / late nights.

pros: Great college campus with a good sized student population. The views and outdoor activities are amazing and are a short trip away. Above average IT and IT support which was nice.
cons: Youre in the middle of no where, It takes an hour to get to the mall and if you want anything more than wal-mart or ingles its about 30 minutes.

pros: Laid back work. Easier than fast food and same pay. Coworkers are usually other college students, so work isn't too boring. My boss is really nice and accommodating.
cons: The experience won't necessarily be useful when you apply for your first job. Still try to get internships if that's a thing in your field.

pros: Tucked away in the mountains of North Carolina, this campus is set into a beautiful lanscape of relatively unspoiled nature. There are some genuinely warm and friendly people there.
cons: The campus is isolated from larger talent pools for positions and other similar bodies for peer interaction in the workplace. There is a marked lack of diversity in the employees and student body.

pros: Beautiful area, great colleagues, good students, lots of opportunity to improve the program, solid faculty support and professional development opportunity
cons: Pay is ok but the lack of collective bargaining leaves salaries stagnant. In addition, state benefits are VERY expensive and paltry. This shortfall is not made up for in other compensation.
